summary: During a forbidden excursion to see the surface world, a goldfish princess encounters a human boy named Sosuke, who gives her the name Ponyo. Ponyo longs to become human, and as her friendship with Sosuke grows, she becomes more humanlike. Ponyo's father brings her back to their ocean kingdom, but so strong is Ponyo's wish to live on the surface that she breaks free, and in the process, spills a collection of magical elixirs that endanger Sosuke's village.

reviews.content: A great movie to watch with the family
This film was silly 👎
Beautiful animation, wonderful score and great characters.
Visually this movie was so cool to watch- bits of humor and just intriguing thought was a nice watch.
not the best ghibli movie, maybe the worst one tbh
I know a lot of people don't like this movie and it is understandable, but this is still a very charming movie and is one of my favorites from studio ghibli.
Great visuals/artistry and a cute story.
This one was freaky, but in a good way. Each character had their charm, the animation was nicely fluid. And the story overall was entertaining. I hate the ocean, but I didn't hate Ponyo.
Love the visuals, ending could've been snappier. Still a fantastic movie.
Is a cute film, even though most of it is very weird and fun sometimes. 7.8/10
Very fun and inquisitive story with gorgeous visuals.
The very amazing and i love the part ponyo run in a water i loved more films to studios ghibli but ponyo is my favorite film .

This movie does well to project the quirkiness of the main character in the animation as well as music surrounding her. They make a point to have more detail on the adult characters and leave the children a bit more cartoonish which I loved. It makes it very clear the mindsets and tone of each of the characters. Though it is based on the story of The Little Mermaid, it does well to set itself apart from it. The interactions between the two child main characters are very fun and cute from their first interaction throughout this literal "fish out of water" story. The movie's score is fantastic and provides a great balance between the humorous and more fantastical elements of the story. The major events that happen during the film are not seen by everyone as very serious which can make it a bit confusing when it comes to the stakes of the film. It also hurts when it is made to be a story of true love between two children when it is not necessary. They just as well could have just been an enduring friendship and demonstrate the bond of loyalty and love on something other than a romantic level.

This film is one that I cannot begin to explain. It's magic, it's just a sight to see and a film I've loved since a child and since just re watching it had to put a review for it. I just love this movie, with all of my heart. Please watch it if you haven't or if you have it's perfect!
This is arguably Miyazaki's most underrated film. It is absolutely excellent and a joy to watch.

WHAT?!!! A horrible mess of disjointed ideas, with some clumsy environmental warnings and vague references to the evolution of life in Earth (random, out-of-context, references to Devonian seas and the pre-Cambrian era). Some nice illustration, but utterly nonsensical and the plot development/story arc is completely arbitrary. Very overrated on Rotten Tomatoes.
Hayao Miyazaki was inspired to make this film after watching 'The Little Mermaid', but he's created something that even surpasses the former in quality and imagination.
Ponyo >>>>>>> The Little Mermaid
Great directing by Hayao Miyazaki, but no likable characters

This was definitely inspired by Silly Symphonies "King Neptune" I wanna see that octopus get his own movie tho. I love Ponyo, if I ever want to remember what being a kid was like I just have to watch the scenes with Sasuke and his mom riding in the car.
Special Effects: 1,0/Sound Effects: 1,0/Acting: 1,0/Story: 2,0

This is not my absolute favourite from Miyazaki, but I still loved it. Ponyo was very magical and charming. I did feel though the ending could have had a little more to it, I am not sure whether I'd use the word incomplete but it didn't leave me completely satisfied. Small criticism aside, the animation is exquisite, typical Miyazaki really- Ethereal colours, beautiful backgrounds and interesting character designs make up the animation here. Another delight was the music, melodious, memorable and of sheer beauty. The script is good too, and I also loved the simple yet magical story and the charming characters especially the very sweet protagonist. The voice acting is top notch too, it is quite emotive and never feels bland. In conclusion, really quite charming and I wouldn't mind seeing it again. 9/10 Bethany Cox

Ponyo is a film with about the same imaginative and magical world as many Ghibli films, with the twist that it is primarily aimed at children before adults, unlike many Ghibli films, with its simply gorgeous child-friendly character design combined with vibrant colors, richness in the environment, particularly scenes in the ocean, and fairly established characters who are super enjoyable to see on screen. While it is not as grandiose as Spirited Away or as poignant as My Neighbor Totoro, it is your normal and literal "fish out of water" story mixed with fantasy that is amusing and appealing to both young and old audiences.

Cute movie for kids with a good animation style. But -1 star cause the mom is a terrible, selfish character. Another -1 star because she stupidly risks her child's life to get to her house, and that just annoyed the crap out of me.

In this Studio Ghibli film, a young human boy, named Sosuke, finds a fish that turns into a little girl. As with most Ghibli films, there is a fantasy element to this film. Maybe it is the dubbed version that lacks world building or explanations of how this fantastic world works, but I needed that during this film. Many characters accepted the fantastical nature of the happenings around them too easily for me. The English dub cast is stacked with talent and they do a good job. The score has moments of epicness that I really enjoyed and the song played over the end credits was catchy. If you enjoy Studio Ghibli films, then this is worth checking out.

Reminded me of other Ghibli not my fav. but visually stunning. It is more for little kids, but yea the creativity of the flow of story and symbolism, the visuals, and music is amazing. has the typical evil anime wizard as one of the characters.  The plot could've been better, but Ponyo was adorable. short film add it to the collection!
This movie is a fucking fever dream, and I love it.
I like the movie I give it a 10 out of 10
Now my heart is full of love TF?
I loved this movie since I was a little kid.
So simple, yet so cute and pretty. A very heartwarming story.

Another triumph for Hayao Miyazaki, Ponyo is an adventurous movie that succeeds as amazing all-ages entertainment. It truly stays wonderfully weird throughout, and even if it sometimes feels a bit much, it is a classic Studio Ghibli film, as many are.

"Ponyo" is a sweetly innocent and charming adventure that while is certainly geared for children, has plenty of appeal for all ages. The theme of this movie is a simple yet true one and I enjoyed watching it. The film's tone reminded me a lot of "My Neighbor Totoro." Even though there is more of a conflict here, I don't think it is quite as strong as that movie. Nonetheless, the characters are likable and the animation is gorgeously colorful and it is a solid addition to the Studio Ghibli roster.

Smart, simple and staggeringly creative, Ponyo is the perfect illustration of Miyazaki's unique style. It catapults you into the story head first. The plot becomes of lesser importance as the story progresses: the depth of the characters will undoubtedly keep you interested all along. With a simple but wonderful story, the 1 hour and 40 minutes felt like a half hour.

Bradley and I LOVED it!!! Kinda weird, the 5 year olds falling in love kinda threw us off a little bit... We were confused for nearly the whole time. Also, what's with the plot? What is the plot? What was the target audience? Did they make this movie on purpose? Was it a joke? Fun movie, seemed like the writers were going through something. Should we be concerned? Has anyone checked on them? Animation was cool! I guess... I wouldn't recommend this movie for kids... or adults who are prone to nightmares... good movie though? 5/5!!!

Ponyo is a charming movie that very much falls in line with the rest of Hayao Miyazaki's filmography. If you like My Neighbor Totoro, then this should be up your alley. It's visual captivating (especially the shoots underwater) with incredibly polite, well-meaning characters and a little bit of plot sprinkled in too. While this movie doesn't have the depth of some of Studio Ghibli's other offerings in terms of themes (humans vs nature is the centerpiece here), it has enough to satisfy adult and child viewers.
An adorable film with fantastical visuals and lovable characters. Studio ghibli truly is something special!

According to Miyazaki, the name "Ponyo" is an onomatopoetic neologism for what "squishy softness" feels like to touch. This etymological explanation takes on new value when considered in light of animation supervisor Katsuya Kondō attempt to transform the artistry of the film into an argument for traditional hand-drawn animation. Now consider the impressionistic backgrounds: What level of algorithmic realism can capture the ambiguities of light and memory and childhood ecstasy like that? Now consider the water: Software no doubt can perfectly replicate the ocean drop for drop, but it does not come close to the way the waves here express the wetness and the tide. This is onomatopoetic animation, joyous and creative and bursting with reality.

Miyazaki's version of the little mermaid. Ponyo, a magical goldfish princess, met a young boy and tried to become human while unleashing the elixirs that threatened to destroy the village. 

What an enjoyable and cute fantasy. The animation of the sea, as well as the creatures, was marvelous and gorgeous. I definitely felt the beauty and power of the sea. 

Ponyo was the best part of the movie. When she played with the ocean, the experience reminded me of the woah and the fun from My Neighbor Totoro. Then, her relationship with the young boy was very cute and enjoyable. 

Hayao Miyazaki once again depicted another aspect of the relationship between human and nature. Before, it was human and the jungle, now it was with the sea. In particular, he showed the effect of pollution on the sea. Then, try though the beautiful animation, the director again reminded us of the power of nature and its potential of striking back. 

Overall, another masterpiece from Miyazaki that kids and adults can all enjoy. 9/10

Definitely a strange one but incredibly cute without being too overloading with it.  A little fish turns into a girl to be close to the little boy she met, magic and hijinks then occur.  What sticks out with me after watching this film is what an insane driver Lisa is, how did that woman get her license?   It also bugged me a little that a fish from the ocean is fine in salt water but given the magical elements I suppose I need to let that slide, heh.
I absolutely love this movie! One that is entertaining for both children and adults.

Adorable anime for children of all ages.

Hayao Miyazaki directs his family comedy anime Ponyo (2008) is perfect for kids that need some dreamy entertainment. Studio Ghibli's hand drawn animation is as vibrant and alive as ever with Ponyo. Every splash of a puddle or crash of an ocean wave feels majestic and lovingly crafted by these Japanese master animators. Miyazaki's direction is swift and sure with a clear focus on making every fish as cute as possible and every moment with Ponyo an infectious revelry. Miyazaki never lost his creative edge or passion for directing as Ponyo proves with its endearing sweetness and effortless charm.

Furthermore, Miyazaki's love of nature continues with Ponyo as it is a cute little romantic comedy with a boy who falls in love with a little girl mermaid, but it's also about humanity polluting the ocean waters with garbage. Ponyo's father only hates humans because of our desecrating the seas with trash and you really feel for him. Miyazaki's writing also bears this warm familial bond between fathers and their daughters as well as mothers and their sons. Miyazaki's writing never fails to provide a strong female lead in his daring heroine Ponyo with her resolute convictions. Ponyo is Miyazaki's love letter to close families, good parenting, and fast friendship all through the eyes of the innocent.

Ponyo may turn off some dour, loveless, jaded adults, who beg Hayao Miyazaki for a mature and sensible anime film, but for those desiring a fun sea adventure feature, Ponyo delivers. It's one of the most adorable movies I've ever seen with radiant colors and lighting, flowing water animation, and a plethora of sea life to look at in the background. Studio Ghibli's animators breathe life into a vast array of fish with funny aquatic designs that rival the cute character designs. Ponyo's underwater wizard father Fujimoto looks so cool and memorable, that his image has stayed with me. Liam Neeson's voice is stern and fatherly, but also has a tenderly vulnerable side that only Neeson could voice with such sincerity. Neeson sounds like he had a blast voicing Ponyo's concerned dad Fujimoto. Liam Neeson is my favorite aspect of Ponyo. He makes a great water wizard to be sure.

Hayao Miyazaki and Takeshi Seyama's editing is intricately cut between Ponyo's seaside adventures on land and her father's worries on the ocean floor. Their quick cuts allow Ponyo to breathe gently in each scene that you get to know her and have fun, while never dragging. Ponyo is a very fast 100 minutes of playful whimsy.

Atsushi Okui's cinematography is lovely with pleasant wide shots of breathtaking ocean views and seaside vistas. His medium shots of people are quite charming. I'm glad Hayao Miyazaki keeps using Okui for his keen eye for cute animated shots and clever framing. Noboru Yoshida's art direction is really neat for Ponyo as the film has this traditional Japanese animation for certain schools of fish, while blending into watery chaos for other styles and moments within Ponyo. Ghibli went ultra creative with Ponyo's visual appearance and watery imagery.

Joe Hisaishi's delightful score is upbeat and brilliant. His cheery music contributes an energy and vivid dynamic to Ponyo's treacherous adventures in the ocean with dreamy melodies for gentle playtime to soaring exuberance for Ponyo's whimsical aquatic nonsense. Joe Hisaishi is a genius film composer. His symphonies cuddle with Ponyo's delirious atmosphere of careless joy and childlike wonder.

Noah Cyrus' excitable and innocent voice for Ponyo herself is probably the peak of her career. She's commanding, surreal, silly, and sincere all in one vocal performance. Her intense playfulness gives Ponyo a real personality. She has erratic chemistry with the likable Frankie Jonas as young Sosuke, the boy who saves Ponyo from a tiny jar. Tina Fey is excellent and endearing as Sosuke's sympathetic mother Lisa. 

Matt Damon is fun and sounds kind as Sosuke's father Koichi. Cate Blanchett cameos as Ponyo's mother and sea goddess Gran Mamere. Cloris Leachman and Betty White cameo as these pleasant elderly ladies with an astute charm of their own.

In conclusion, I know it may seem childish to love Ponyo, but Ponyo is so easy going and affectionate that I cannot help but adore this movie. I loved Ponyo when it released back in 2008 and it holds up beautifully.

Ponyo ignores the world of Disney and carves its own course.   Probably more beloved by critics and animation experts, Ponyo only wows if you have a taste for efforts pushing the boundary of narrative in ways only animation can.  Standout features for me:
- A rare positive and explicit evocation of the Divine Feminine in Ponyo's mother,
- A fluid childlike art style perfectly suited to animating hundreds of watery scenes,
- The creepiness of a fairy enticed to become human thru human blood is neither ignored nor exploited,
- The supporting nursing home characters evolve suprisingly. 
Adroit in multiple ways Ponyo is an animated wonder. 
Ponyo (also known as Ponyo on the Cliff) (2008)
A different type of love story.

Sort of a "cuteness overload" film that manages to have some tension and excitement as well.

There are some weird implications in the plot, best not to think about those too much.
Ponyo is a beautifully animated and adorable adventure from the mind of Hayao Miyazaki offering a touching tale for audiences of all ages.
There is no story. Movie should be presented with visuals only and no dialogue. Would be just as impactful.

From the imagery that sparks the imagination of any child, to the way Sosuke views his mother as the strongest person in his life. Ponyo is one of the best portrayals of childhood innocence you can watch.
Another visual delight, this is my least favorite Miyazaki movie so far. It just never fully clicked with me and meandered on at points.
Such an engaging movie. The acts of the kids are so realistic.
It was entertaining in that it had that Ghibli quality and heart to it. Beyond that... The story was basic, buy yet I would watch it again.
visually stunning fairy tale that's a sweetly poetic treat for children of all ages

If I had to describe Ponyo as succinctly as possible, it would be "excessively cute", almost to the point of overindulgence. Don't get me wrong, the film is beautifully animated and very much enjoyable, but it often feels like it's more style over substance, failing to explore any mature theme in depth like many other Ghibli greats. For instance, the treatment of the tsunami, a major plot device, is surprisingly lighthearted given Japan's rather devastating history in this context; this film probably couldn't have been released a few years later, following the extreme loss of life in 2011. Lacking a sense of sincerity and gravitas, Ponyo feels almost sickly sweet at times, but even pure sugar tastes good for the first few minutes. Overall, still entertaining, but not without weaknesses. (4/5)
i remember watching this when i was a little kid and i thought it was a good movie

This movie is really cute. Whenever I watch this movie it reminds me of My Neighbour Totoro and how I thought the same feelings I have with this movie. Even though it felt a little tiny bit similar to My Neighbour Totoro I still love this movie for what it is and for sure recommend this movie.

A more strictly child-friendly film than others in the Ghibli cannon. Apparently inspired by the 'Little Mermaid' stories popularised in the modern era by Disney, which originated from the Hans Christian Anderson fairy-tale. Fun to watch for its more bizarre moments, such as the villainous wizard's underwater lair housing his anthropomorphic seamonkey-esque children, along with his ability to float on water and jellyfish. Occasional weak plot points in the story and its more innocent portrayal reduced my enjoyment somewhat, but still a great film in its own right - albeit paling in comparison to the greater Ghibli works (Princess Mononoke, Spirited Away, Howls Moving Castle, My Neighbor Totoro)
What a beautifully told story, just the cutest thing ever, I loved it!

Although ponyo may be one of Ghiblis simpler stories it doesn't shy away from the fact the film is amazing, and who ever said a simple story was bad? Although I agree that stories should usually have depth and detail I've seen films such as this with a simple story succeed in emotion and writing talent. For anyone who's looking for a trip to the coast without moving, this films for you!
the story line, especially the part how the kid saved the world is very underwelming. it's more of a kid movie.

The Little Mermaid, only younger and cuter, through the perspective of a child. And to think all animation, including water effects were all hand-drawn, really goes to show Studio Ghibili's great artistic talents.
A visually stimulating fairy tale and a poetic romance story aimed to people of all ages.
very good, and good actors in english
Beautiful animation, charming characters. Not the best Miyazaki film, but still very good.
Exactly what I was looking for. This is a beautiful and well-written piece of cinema that stands among Miyazaki's best work.

One of the later efforts from Hayao Miyazaki. It's about a fish becoming a real girl as five year old Sôsuke picks her up from the ocean. She enters the real world, or maybe Sôsuke is entering a fantasy water world, but this is a ride where rising water is threatening the life as we know it. Villains, friends, moms and sandwitches are all playing an important part in this vivid tale.

It has that nice Ghibli look and it's fascinating for both young and older. It's not as good as the best gems from Miyazaki but I'd place it somewhere in the middle among his films. It's more juvenile than his greatest, but still carries a lot of wisdom and depth. A nice finger is pointed towards humans and the ocean littering we are doing and some other more dreamy hints and pointings are also done.

7.5 out of 10 slices of ham.
Must see for families! Introduced me to anime in a whole new aspect. Will always be one of my top favs!

There were some 5-star sequences in this movie. The storm sequence is spectacular. However, the plot got way too complex and "talky" at the end. 

It's a good movie, but it just doesn't compare to Princess Mononoke and Spirited Away.

Absolutely winning animation along with a somewhat silly yet strongly charming, mature and unique story make ‘Ponyo' another great entry in studio ghibli's collection.
8.5/10, B+
Ponyo makes me long for my own childhood and the sort of youthful imagination that went along with it.

From the mind of Hayao Miyazaki comes Ponyo, the beautifully animated retelling of The Little Mermaid which also has really well-done voice acting in the English dub, a story that's laid-back (in fact, a bit too laid-back. There are remarkable cases of "angst? what angst?" from the citizens even when their home is flooded) and sweet imagination despite some things going unexplained. A great animated film from the likes of Studio Ghibli.
On the big screen, the movie is brought to life, with all of the ocean swells and sea life. It’s an adorable, heart-warming story.
Hayao Miyazaki put an incredible movie together that is a great must watch for all ages.
The whole movie was done through a child's perspective and imagination which was really nice and took me back to being a kid. It really is a poetic film. Amazing colour in the animation also.
Too depressing and gloomy. You never understand what is going on exactly. Wanna waste your time? watch Ponyo
the only movie to exist
Miyazakis animation is fabulous!  I love the underwater scene!
A bit disappointing in comparison to the rest of Miyazaki's work
I freaking love this movie
I love this movie it's my favourite I like the animation and the soundtrack is good

A young boy rescues a goldfish and a bond forms that allows the fish to turn into a young girl and come onto land in search of the boy.  This sets off an imbalance that threatens both land and sea.  In many ways, this is the oddest of Miyazaki's films with both the plot and the animation being a lot more impressionistic than his typical work.  It's also more solidly aimed at children than his previous few films.  Still, although it's not among his very best films, it's a beautifully animated film.

The usual dosage of cute imagination, peculiar fantasy and sticky sweetness we've come to expect from a major Studio Ghibli picture. Set in a small port town, Ponyo is the tale of an independent young boy, effectively living in a single-parent household with his father continually at sea, who discovers an odd creature with shifting human features at the water's edge. In Hayao Miyazaki's hands, the ocean is a wild, vibrant collection of churning life, and its residents (particularly that one determined, shape-shifting fish) an irresistible, elemental force of passion and curiosity. It's alive and adorable, though not something to be taken lightly, as we discover when a raging storm hammers the coast and floods our little town. Generally quiet, low-key and contemplative, it's a much smaller journey than enveloping masterpieces like Princess Mononoke and Spirited Away. Ghibli's earlier works are a better comparison, particularly My Neighbor Totoro which deals with many similar moods and themes in a forest environment. A small-scale, feel-good film that's an excellent opportunity to shut down the critical mind and give in to the sense of childish wonder that permeates Ghibli's best scenes, though not quite the sweeping epic that the studio's become known for of late.
So good!! I got this from my friend and I thought it would be stupid just because like it didn't look good. But it is awesome!!!!!!!!
Still one of my favourite movies of all time. Always will love it. Amazing animation and art style, especially with its water effects. Absolutely beautiful and fantastic plot as well.

Not the best Studio Ghibli I've seen but still solid and engaging, this is their left of field take on the classic mermaid tale in many ways.  Both my boys enjoyed this on a take it easy day in front of the TV and I found it pretty charming as well.

The idea of this film is really out there and unique just like all the other studio ghibli movies. The animation is beautiful, I mean just look at the water! Ponyo is a wonderful movie that I would definitely share with other people. Everyone deserves to watch this fairy tale movie.
Absolutely adorable and fun all the way through. Any person of any age can enjoy this film

I’m sure this was supposed to be a cute movie about the innocence of youth and the purity of love... Or at least something along that line. And I understand that this is just a movie and obviously does not reflect real life at all. But it’s really absurd to think that a pair of 5 year olds would know the true meaning of love. Sure, they could adore each other but it’s doubtful their “love” would carryover into adulthood. We are talking about children who could change their mind about their favourite cartoon/character/toy etc...within a year. And what kind of irresponsible parent would leave their child alone (or in charge of another child) during a massive tsunami!?!? Seriously!!! What kind of nonsense is that? Yes, I’m being extremely cynical (and critical) but it’s the truth. This would make sense if the children were at least a pre-teen/teenager. Sure, the animation was great. It’s what you should expect from Ghibli. Still, one of my least favourite movies. I would only recommend it to kids under the age of 10.

It's not one of Studio Ghibli's best, but it still has all the traits that make what they do very unique. But, I would recommend you to switch the distracting, A-list celebrity dub from Disney and just go subtitled.
A re-telling of the Little Mermaid, and a lot of movie magic.
Bruh I f*cking loved this movie when I was little!
an incredible and fun film that will bring joy to both kids and adults alike, not as good as some of Studio Ghibli's other work but still phenomenal
this is a great movie

Ponyo is the name of the goldfish given by the 5 year old boy, Sosuke  who saved her upon having her head stuck in a bottle. Once Sosuke introduces to her to foods such as ham as well as her healing powers motivate her to wanting to become human too with the dad going against it.

Disney's 'The Little Mermaid' with toddlers, for toddlers. 'Ponyo' seems to be made with a much younger audience in mind which, for me, made it slightly less enjoyable than some of Miyazaki's other work geared towards somewhat older viewers, but there's no denying that it's a beautiful and magical hand-drawn film with a very sweet story and, as with most of Miyazaki's work, an important message to deliver. Another lovely entry into the iconic director's filmography.
It has such an endearing weirdness about it.

I really wanted to like this one more, being a massive Miyazaki fanboy, but I can't.  The story, while charming doesn't really go anywhere or expose any new or original ideas.  BUT the animation is so damn gorgeous that it is definitely still worth checking out.  This is bonafide anime eye candy at it's finest.

Amazing the amount of animation and movement, sea creatures that fill the screen in that beginning scene. Ponyo looks so cute. The colors and animation are stunning in this movie. I can see the inspiration this movie had on the movie, The Red Turtle.

Wow, some o the scenes in this movie are spectacular, the way they animated this movie is gorgeous. A visual treat indeed. That kids mother drives like a freaking mad man.

It's so lovely to see a little girl who has powers put it to good use by helping out others. Ponyo's mother is beautiful, a true goddess. Such a goodhearted and sweet movie. 

Though the story is not as filling as other Miyazaki films, it's a very genuine one and a sweet one. The characters in this movie all have goodhearted intentions and are easily likable. It's a very cute movie, definitely Miyazaki's most children oriented movie. 

The visuals were really eye catching and beautiful. You can really see his love for the colors blue and green. All the sea creatures were so intersting to watch. There were some that looked really ominous and creepy.

Overall, wonderful movie with captivating visuals. So beautiful that they make me want to be there in that little village.

Great movie. While some of its plot certainly feels reminiscent of The Little Mermaid and it's formulaic in moments, it still features so many unique elements, breathtaking animation and heartwarming storytelling.
I'll be putting this movie on over and over for my kids when I have them.  Liam Neeson in it is a plus!

The setup is perfect and the idea is charming and intriguing. Ponyo is more than our Little Mermaid of fairytale fame - she's determined, powerful and kind of sweet in a weird, yelling, blobby sort of way. However she suffers from the usual Ghibli flaw - the weak final act where the tone settles down and never manages to pick up again. Character motivations dwindle and suddenly very little makes sense but everyone seems to be ok with it. Also, while the environmental message is not without credit, it's ineffective and heavy handed to the point of preachy coming from one character only. Mononoke-Hime did a much better job.
While the animation is beautiful and the visual design stunning, I can't help but feel that, while good, is one of "Studio Ghibli's weaker films.
One of the better Studio Ghibli films. Totally weird concepts that work very well.
Not particularly profound when compared to other Miyazaki, Ponyo is still a cute story in the vein of My Neighbor Totoro.

This film moved me in a way that other Ghibli Films didn't. The first few minutes are spectacular and stunning. Sosuke is great character and has depth to him, and I can relate to him in a lot of ways, while Lily is angry, hardy, but you see that she's a wonderful person that keeps here sad emotions bottled up inside, and the elders really open up at the end. This is the most well-done Studio Ghibli film I have ever seen, and I think that anybody who says it's a rip-off of Finding Nemo, this is much better than that. Anybody who hears about this needs to watch it.
great watch all the time

Hayao Miyazaki has accomplished the tri-fecta by successfully writing, directing and animating Ponyo. He continues his magic with an absolute jaw-dropping and crowd-pleasing work of art. It has sweetness and charm that will rip your socks right off your stinky feet. I was tickled pink; grinned from ear to ear; eyes completely open; trying to wake up from this imaginary fantasy world that Ponyo puts you in. It's simple, fresh, breathtaking, and incredibly sophisticated and it's one of Miyazaki's finest without a doubt.
Love all of their movies and more.
Cutest characters and an excellent storyline

Definitely not Miyazaki's best offering, but "Ponyo" is pure enough satisfy those whose having a bad day or needs a realm to escape to. It's magical and colorful. The film's only weakness is the lack of antagonist. Without any sense of threat, then what's the point of us caring for our protagonists? Kids will love it, but for adults, they will probably snooze right through it.

Ponyo is magical, innocent, and charming.
Hayao Miyazaki might be the king of Fantasy genre. It is fascinating how his mind works. I wish I could live in his imagination. The world he created in this movie is pure innocent, and I love that. In this movie, the world is not black and white. It's always white and that's a good thing. The story is not epic, instead we get a simple lovely story. Visually, Ponyo wowed me in the same way Howl's Moving Castle, Princess Mononoke, and Laputa: Castle in the Sky did to me. The fantasy world in Ponyo is breathtaking. I had no intention to watch Ponyo, but I gave it a try. Well, in the end, I fell in love with it.
I LOVE THIS MOVIE SOO MUCH
One of the greatest animated film of all time

Miyazaki's weirdest, most insane movie. Also maybe Miyazaki's most beautifully animated movie. And yet this one slots in next to Porco Rosso at the bottom of my Miyazaki faves in that it's fun and it's a great movie but just didn't connect the way the way his movies usually (read: almost always) connect. I do love that they obviously tried to reel in the Finding Nemo crowd with the borderline facsimile poster and DVD art when this movie might disturb some of the more square parents out there.

Another Miyazaki flick to enjoy! Absolutely outstanding animation hand-drawn. As for the story may be a little bit off places some places, but I digress. This film is very enjoyable to watch for all ages to come. This movie is simply cute! Love, it's very strong and is very strong in this film and I like it. 

Grade 
8.5/10
